730777f-a.title: Bridges - George Washington Bridge - [North (Hudson) River.]
730777f-a.text:
George Washington Bridge: The Manhattan support as viewed southward
on the Hudson River. Note the light house at its base. This is the last
of its kind left on the island of Manhattan.
July 19, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(Not a dry mount item).

730771f-a.title: Bridges - George Washington Bridge.
730771f-a.text:
U. S. Naval Cruisers, Portland and Northampton, riding and anchor be-
neath the majestic span of the George Washington Bridge. The sailing ship
is the Tusitala.
June 6, 1934.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

730766f-c.title: Bridges - George Washington Bridge.
730766f-c.text:
(1)
The George Washington Bridge spans the beautiful Hudson River, in
connecting Fort Lee N.J., to West 181st Street Manhattan. View is
looking west to the N. J. Palisades.
September 29, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(2)
The George Washington Bridge, as seen from fill near 165th Street
and Riverside Drive, looking westward at Ne Jersey.
September 29, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(3)
The same, showing the Waverly Boat Club; as seen from about 167th
Street and Riverside Drive.
September 29, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

The George Washington Bridge, as viewed southwestward across
Riverside Drive and the Hudson River, from Fort Tryon Park. This

Englewood, New Jersey.
June 22, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.

the spun cables connecting the pier heads prior to the suspension
of the cat--walk.

730758f-b.text:
George WashiNton Bridge: Three views showing the
construction beriod attendant to this public work that
connects Manhattan, New York to Wew Jersey.
The first two views are of the New York Approach
while the third is of the Jersey side.

View : 3 August 1929

730759f-a.title: Bridges - George Washington Bridge - [North (Hudson) River.]
730759f-a.text:
George Washington Bridge: A northward view up the North (Hudson)
Rtiver showing the cables and piers of the uncompleted structure.
Manhattan is on the right and New Jersey on the left. Note the
United States Navy vessels off of Riverside Drive. View No. 2 is a
close up of the Manhattan base. Note here, at the left, the small
lighthouse on a promontory, the historic significance of which goes
back to the Revolution, as it was from here that the chains extended
across the River. Apartments seen in the background form the area
known as Washington Heights.
May 10, 1930
dnift of W. A. Lucas
CRDDIT LINE IMPERATIVE ON ALL REPRODUCTIONS

730762f-a.text:
Four square blocks of modern apartment buildings; sacrificed to make
clearance for the Manhattan approach to the George Washington Bridge, at
approximately Wiest 181st Street, in Manhattan.
Late 1930.7
Ewing Galloway.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

730775f-c.title: Bridges - George Washington Bridge - [Connecting Manhattan at West 181st Street with Fort Lee, New Jersey.]
730775f-c.text:
The George Washington Bridge, a steel structure, connecting Manhattan
at West 181st Street with Fort Lee, New Jersey. The view is westward from
Manhattan, and just south of the Bridge. Control of this engineering
Rsterpieoe, is in the hands of the N.Y. Port Authority, who will charge a
toll for crossing same. These 4 views are more or less similar, and are
all by the sage photographer.
1936.
Walter L. Bogert.
NO REPPODUCTIONS.

730779f-b.title: Bridges - George Washington Bridge - [North (Hudson) River.]
730779f-b.text:
George 4ashington Bridge: A set of 2 views southwestward
from Dr. Chas. V. Paterno's estate on the east bank of the North
(Hudson) River, showing this span connecting Manhattan with Jersey
thru a ribhon of steel. The castlelloted structure at the left is
the home of the aforementioned individual and is at this time being
razed to provide an apartment site. For views see Cahrini Blvd.
Aumust 23, 1938.
Viewsl and 2
P. L. Sperr
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

730757f-a.title: Bridges - George Washington Bridge - [Construction of the world's longest suspension bridge.]
730757f-a.text:
Rush Construction of 7orld's Longest Suspension Bridge.
Right, construction work on one of the piers of the grsat Hudson
River Bridge which will be opened in 1932 at a cost of ab out 170
million. The Bridge will connect Manhattan(lower right) between
178th Street and 179th Street and Fort Lee, New Jersey(left)
where another pier bs shown. The distance between the two piers,
fron which the Sridge will be suspended, is 3,500 feet -- over
twice the length of the longest suspension bridge at peesent
(Cannden-Philadelphia span).
n.d.  Underwood and Underwood
